rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:1–5
rsbNotes.text: 2:1–5 Zechariah’s third vision describes a man with a measuring line. This vision stresses God’s protection of His people with His own personal presence (v. 5 notes). Jerusalem’s walls were probably not rebuilt yet, and the city was subject to attack from roving bands.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:1
rsbNotes.text: 2:1 a measuring line. An implement that became a symbol of rebuilding in Jeremiah’s portrayal of a restored Jerusalem (Jer. 31:39).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:4
rsbNotes.text:
2:4 without walls. The Old Testament prophets envision a time when Jerusalem will be the center of worship for the nations (v. 11; 8:20–23; Is. 2:1–4), and the city will overflow with people.

multitude of people and livestock. See note on v. 11.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:5
rsbNotes.text:
2:5 a wall of fire all around. The day of full restoration is portrayed by the prophets as a second Exodus with the imagery of the pillar of fire (Is. 4:5, 6). As Israel was once protected from her enemies by God Himself, so He will again guard her from oppressors.

the glory. God’s presence is far more than protection; it is the source of all blessing for His people. The essence of the renewed covenant is, “I will be their God, and they shall be my people” (Jer. 31:33).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:6–13
rsbNotes.text: 2:6–13 In this section the prophet speaks to the Jews in Babylon (vv. 6–9) and in Jerusalem (vv. 10–13).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:6
rsbNotes.text: 2:6 I have spread you abroad. A reference to God’s judgment of Judah in the Exile as punishment for covenant disobedience (Deut. 28:36, 49, 50). The time of judgment is over; the time of restoration has come (v. 7).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:8
rsbNotes.text: 2:8 the apple of his eye. See note Deut. 32:10.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:10
rsbNotes.text: 2:10 I will dwell in your midst. This promise assumes the sanctification of the people and land through the blood of the everlasting covenant (3:9 notes; 8:8 note; Heb. 13:20).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:11
rsbNotes.text: 2:11 many nations. The extent of the vision transcends anything the Jews could accomplish in their day. The vision captures a time when salvation will not be limited to the Jewish nation but will extend God’s grace to the world. That day has come in Christ’s inauguration of the kingdom of God.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:12
rsbNotes.text: 2:12 in the holy land. An expression used only here in the Scriptures. Judah will be holy because God will dwell there. Zechariah is envisioning the fullest realization of God’s promise to Abraham (Gen. 12:3; 15:5).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 2:13
rsbNotes.text:
2:13 Be silent. All mankind should revere God because of the great salvation declared in this chapter (Hab. 2:20).

he has roused himself. For the purpose of judgment. God will both judge the nations that oppressed His people and provide a safe home for His people.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–10 The fourth vision concerns Joshua, the high priest (Ezra 3:2), and deals particularly with the problem of an impure priesthood. It begins by showing God’s solution to the problem (vv. 4, 5) and ends by showing how God wipes away the sin of all His people (vv. 8, 9).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:1
rsbNotes.text:
3:1 A courtroom scene similar to that in Job (Job 1:6–12). Satan has come to accuse Joshua of his unworthiness for the priesthood. The Hebrew term Satan means “adversary” or “accuser” (text note); here it may be descriptive (i.e., not a proper name).

standing. Joshua assumes the position of the priest who ministers in the presence of God. Accusation is a favorite ploy of Satan against believers. It differs from the conviction of the Holy Spirit. The Spirit convicts of sin in order to move us to repentance and forgiveness. Satan’s goal is destruction, not redemption.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:2
rsbNotes.text: 3:2 brand plucked from the fire. The fire is a metaphor for the Exile from which the people of God have been snatched. Amos 4:11 also uses the same expression to speak of the danger from which God redeems His people.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:3
rsbNotes.text: 3:3 filthy garments. Here we see the basis of Satan’s accusations that Joshua is unworthy. If the high priest is unclean, who can make atonement for sin? If he cannot make the atonement, how can the people be forgiven? The answer is given in a twofold manner below.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:4
rsbNotes.text: 3:4 Remove the filthy garments. God makes Joshua fit for the priesthood by giving new garments. In this way Joshua is a type of the coming Branch (v. 8), who will fulfill a priestly function and provide clothing of righteousness for us from His own merit.

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 a clean turban. The turban was part of the high priest’s dress. A new clean turban completes the restored garments, indicating that God has taken away the reproach on the priesthood (Ex. 28:36–38).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:8
rsbNotes.text:
3:8 they are men who are a sign. These men foreshadow the coming Servant because they are priests, and He will act as a priest by making atonement for sin (v. 9 note).

my servant. A title of honor initially used for Moses (Num. 12:6–8). The term also was used as a title in Isaiah, sometimes for Israel (Is. 41:8; 44:1, 2) and sometimes (as here) for the Messiah, the Servant who would redeem His people (Is. 42:1–7; 52:13).

the Branch. A Messianic title combining the offices of priest and king (6:12 note: Is. 4:2 and note).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:9
rsbNotes.text:
3:9 the stone. Possibly a reference to the Messiah. Several Old Testament passages about the stone were interpreted as messianic in the New Testament (Ps. 118:22; Is. 8:14; 28:16; Matt. 21:42; 1 Pet. 2:6–8).

seven eyes. The mixture of images is difficult to interpret but these eyes are symbols of God’s omniscient and watchful care (also used in 4:10).

remove the iniquity of this land. God will take away His people’s sin through the Branch. The priestly system in the Old Testament was not intended actually to cover sin but only to prefigure the One who would truly deal with man’s sin (Heb. 10:1–18).

in a single day. The Day of Atonement (Lev. 16:30; 23:28) was an annual reminder of sin (Heb. 9:7–10), but Christ on a single day (Good Friday) once for all made atonement for the sins of God’s people (Heb. 9:11–14).

rsbNotes.title: Zech 3:10
rsbNotes.text: 3:10 under his vine . . . fig tree. An expression for peace and prosperity (1 Kin. 4:25; Mic. 4:4). The ultimate state of God’s kingdom is in view.
